intro: Papaver glaucum var. leucum, commonly known as the white poppy, is a variant of the glaucum poppy characterized by its pale to white petals. It is a herbaceous annual plant native to the Mediterranean region, including parts of southern Europe and western Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer, are simple and showy, with a distinctive central stigma. This variety is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been cultivated for both garden use and historical medicinal purposes.
